Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 06:37AM vmudrow wrote: I was told that they can't tell if a fibroadenoma is B9 for sure so they like to remove them (I've had several) - hopefully yours will be B9 - hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: Not sure about fibroadenoma dobiedame dobiedame

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 04:43PM vmudrow wrote: I think they just want to be sure.  I had microcalcifications 2 years ago - biopsied by stereotactic and then in January they were clustering and my BS wanted to do a excisional biopsy to get more of them - it came back atypical lobular hyperlasia - not cancer, but kind of a precancer.  They worry a little when they start clustering more in a certain spot.  Hope yours turns out ok.  Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: Calcifications Question... Follow up after B9 Biopsy... shabby6485 shabby6485

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 07:49AM vmudrow wrote: Hi NYCme - I don't get on here much because my surgery was May 2010 - but decided to today and came across your story.  I was 49 in Jan 2010 and got the diagnosis of ALH (had calcifications and got diagnosis after lumpectomy) - this is after many years of numerous biopsies and a strong family history.  I was tired of the worry and did not want to take Tamoxifen - my surgeon said I was a canidate for nipple/skin sparing masectomies.  I have been really happy with the whole process and made the right decision for me.  There are not too many ladies that have had PBMX because of ALH - but there are a few of us.  Let me know if you have any questions or would like to chat - I'd be happy to talk to you.  Good luck and Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia NYCMs MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 06:54AM vmudrow wrote: I had microcalcifications that were clustering (it's the clustering they worry about), had wire localization biopsy - this was Jan. 2010 - came back ALH - precancerous - it's good they are checking it out.  Let us know what the results are - praying they are B9 for you - hugs, Valerie

Posts.Title: Calcifications Question... Follow up after B9 Biopsy... shabby6485 shabby6485

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 02:29PM vmudrow wrote: Two years ago I had a stereotactic biopsy because of microcalcifications - came back B9 - the test isn't bad, but as stated above your neck will hurt the most from holding it in one spot for an hour.  Sorry to say you will then have to wait a few days for the report to come back.  They put a little metal chip in so they could compare future mammograms to the same spot.  Last year the calcifications were clustering and they wantd to do another stereotactic - I talked to a surgeon and they recommended doing an excisional biopsy to get more of a sampling - came back ALH - precancerous they said.  So try not to worry -but tell them to call as soon as possible with the results - sending positve hugs your way - Valerie

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2010 02:39PM vmudrow wrote: Hi,  I had PBM in May for ALH, I also had strong family history and was tired of all the biopsies etc.   I did have reconstruction - are you sure you don't want it - because mine wasn't cancer they did nipple skin sparing masectomies and I have been very pleased with the result.  If you have any questions let me know.  But make the best decision for you.  The surgery was not bad at all for me, 1 night in hospital, 3 days on pain pills, then tylenol.  Had my exchange surgery 7 weeks ago and feel great.  Good luck!!
Posts.Title: Prophylactic Bilateral Mastectomy Kezzie62 fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2011 06:43AM vmudrow wrote: Good luck on your results - keep us posted.  I too had calcs with ALH.  My options were Tamoxifen and close monitoring or masectomies.  Chose to do PBMX, I couldn't stand the worry with every biopsy/test.  It has been a little over a year and I have been very happy with the whole process.  Hugs, Valerie

Posts.Content: May 5, 2010 07:32AM vmudrow wrote: I had microcalcifications in January - biopsied - ALH.  Oncologist wanted me to take tamoxifen.  I know a few people on it for bc and they HATE the side effects.  Having had several previous biopsies and scares, along with family history (40% risk of getting bc, several family member have had it - mother, aunt, grandmother and cousin), I am having skin sparing masectomies tomorrow - just want to get rid of it all before it becomes cancer.  Surgeon agrees with my decision because I am a worrier.  This way I won't have the side effects of tamoxifen - I am 49.

Posts.Title: Ok, so you canget LE without node removal. iammommy lago

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 09:55AM vmudrow wrote: Just thought I'd chime in - very interesting as I didn't know ALH or ADH existed until I was diagnoised last January.  Because of strong family history, previous biopsies, didn't want side effects of Tamoxifen etc. my surgeon and I chose PBM.  Surgery was in May and October my exchange surgery.  The worry is gone, no Tamoxifen, no mammograms, no MRIs and no biopsies etc.  Not for everyone, but I was ready to be done with the worry and to reduce my risk of bc (I just turned 50).  Good luck to everyone - talk to others and doctors before making any decisions.
Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 09:52AM vmudrow wrote: My Body - Sorry you are feeling so overwhelmed.  I had ALH and I don't think you need to rush into anything.  As for me I didn't want to take Tamoxifen and had a strong family risk and had my risk assessed - 40% of getting breast cancer.  I am 49 and chose to have masectomies - couldn't stand the constant worry and I also felt there might be something else in there.  The surgery for me wasn't too bad at all - May 6, tissue expanders and exchange Oct. 8th - feeling great - no worry and no Tamoxifen and no mammograms or MRIs or biopsies.  (nothing else was found in the removed tissue, except B9 lumps that didn't show up on mammos).  Let us know how you are doing.  hugs, valerie

I have a strong family history, did not want to take tamoxifen (that was the oncologists treatment), I was tired if the worry and the constant monitoring that would be scheduled. Because it wasn't cancer i was able to have nipple sparing, I have been very happy with the whole process. It is a hard decision, let me know if you have ant any questions. Hugs, valerie

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2011 10:05AM vmudrow wrote: hopeful24 - I too had 5 biopsies that were fiboedemoes etc, and last year came back ALH.  I was tired of the constant worrying (strong family history) and tests, biopsies - so I decided to have nipple/skin masectomies.  I have been so happy with the results.  My risk went from 40% down to less than 5% - and I don't have to take Tamoxifen.  I wish everyone good luck with their decisions - it's hard, but I think you find peace once you make a decision.  And for me the masectomies were not that bad...  Hugs, Valerie

Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 06:17AM vmudrow wrote: Unsure123 - I too had very small breasts and there was getting to be nothing left after numerous biopsies.  My implants do feel kind of cold sometimes - doesn't make my body cold, they just feel cold when I touch them.  They are not uncomfortable, did take some getting used to them, but feel great now - it's been almost a year since the whole process.  Good luck - you are not alone - hugs Valerie
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 2 years following IDC Stage II eeyore2515 bdavis

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2010 12:11PM vmudrow wrote: I had had 5 previous biopsies and when my last one came back ALH I finally decided I was done and had PBM, plus I didn't want to go on Tamoxifen.  I do have a strong family history, although no BRCA gene. There were alot of people that thought I was nuts and over doing it, but I did not want to wait until it was cancer.  Even my dad, who saw my mom go through chemo was against it - true it may never have turned to cancer, but I am a worrier and was worn out with worry.  My doctor supported my decision and I had nipple/skin sparing surgery.  Nothing worrisome was found when the breast tissue that was removed was biopsied, except there were multiple B9 lumps, which never showed up on mammograms.  My surgeon said it looked I would have been having biopsies all the time because of the MRIs I would have to have had and anything suspicious would have had to be removed.   I have been very happy with my decision and the results - just my two cents worth.  Good luck with your decision, and you don't need to rush it - if you have any questions let me know. Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 10:36PM vmudrow wrote: Kris2011 - Your experience was very interesting (those stereotactic biopsies are fun aren't they?)  I was diagnoised a year ago with ADH (precancer).  Oncologist wanted me to take Tamoxifen for 5 years and surgeon said I would have to have MRI every year - which would show everything B9 or not, but everything found would have to be biopsied - I think that's what would be a can of worms.  I was 49 and had had 5 previous biopsies - all B9.  I didn't think I could stand having biopsies every year and the worry and I wasn't thrilled about taking Tamoxifen.  After a long discussion with the surgeon she agreed that I was a good canidate for PBM - nipple and skin sparing.  She said my risk would go from 40% chance of getting cancer to less than 5% - so wonder why your doctor said haaving masectomies wouldn't get rid of most of the risk?  I had the surgery and have been very happy with the outcome.  Hope you get some answers.  Going for a second opinion I think you can have all of your records requested by the new doctor.  Good luck and lots of hugs - Valerie
Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 11:21PM vmudrow wrote: Kris2011 - Sorry it took me so long to get back on here.  Beesie is right PMB means prophylylactic (preventative) bilateral mastectomy.  I had nipple/skin sparing masectomies.  I had tissue expanders placed at time of surgery and then exchanged to silicone implants.  For me the whole process was very interesting and really not painful.  The surgery wasn't too bad, on pain pills for 3 days then just tylenol. I had to be careful for 6 weeks and then I was able to play tennis.   I play tennis too!!!  It was strange playing with the TEs, but not bad.  I too find it weird when ladies say they can feel their breasts.  When I touch them lightly I think I feel it, but it's my fingers that are feeling, because if I look away and my DH touches there is no feeling.  When they are touched or squeezed by my husband I feel pressure, but it is just kind of  a weird feeling.  When I play tennis or exercise, especially lifting weights the pec muscle may move and the whole implant kind of moves with it - it's kind of funny.  I am getting used to the impalnts now, it's been 3 months and I went bigger, so it has been an adjustment playing tennis.  What level are you in tennis?  Hopefully I answered some of your questions.  Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 04:07PM vmudrow wrote: Kris - I think the hardest part is making the decision, once I made up my mind I felt at ease.  Just saw the plastic surgeon for my 3 month post op check - and really I feel and look great (at least I think so).  My husband and I are rated 4.5 so I live in Utah - if you ever come here we will have to play.  I love tennis and the friends I have made over the years playing.  It's good for you physically and mentally - so keep it up.  Keep up the posts - so we know how you are doing!!
Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Posts.Title: A question...thinking WAY ahead NurseBeth 2much

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 03:03PM vmudrow wrote: drjanet - The oncologist I talked to said that most of his patients tolerated Tamoxifen well, and didn't have many side effects.  I knew of  a couple of ladies that were taking it and I contacted them and they wished so bad that they didn't have to take it.  The one even told her doctor she was going to stop - and he scared her into keeping on taking it so her breast cancer wouldn't return.  I can't exactly remember their specific side effects but I just decided that I didn't want to risk the side effects plus do the constant monitoring, worrying etc.
Posts.Title: A question...thinking WAY ahead NurseBeth 2much

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 01:05AM vmudrow wrote: wonderfullymade - I don't know the answer to NurseBeth's question - but I was in the same situation as you (although you are much younger), my  mother tested negative for the gene, but when I finally got the diagnosis of ALH (precancerous) I made the decision to have a double masectomy. My risk was figured to be 40%.  I too didn't want the worry every time I had an MRI, plus because it was precancerous the oncologits wanted me to take Tamoxifen, which I didn't want to do.  I hope your test is negative, but you still have options.  Hugs, Valerie

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 07:33AM vmudrow wrote: Glad to hear I'm not the only one who finds the TE's uncomfortable.  I had my second fill yesterday of 60 cc.  It is the weirdest feeling when they squirt in the saline.  The PS says he knows, how does he "know", he's never had it done.  He laughed and said, "well I've heard", he is very nice.  Now up to 170 cc, was really sore last night and had trouble sleeping.  I told my husband it feels like having two cans of corn duct taped onto your chest and then try walking, moving and sleeping!!!  This morning it doesn't really hurt, just really tight.  3 weeks ago today was my nipple,skin sparing masectomies.  I go next week for a fill and then PS will probably wait 2 weeks for the next one.  This has been a very interesting process...

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2011 09:58AM vmudrow wrote: When I was diagnoised with ALH the oncologist said that Tamoxifen was the preferred treatment.  He said most of his patients don't have any side effects from it.  I however found some ladies on it called them and they hated being on it -but felt they couldn't go off because they had breast cancer.  I chose PBMX - now no Tamoxifen, no MRIs, my risk went from 40% to less that 5% - I see the surgeon once a year.  Good luck - it's a hard decision.  Maybe you could try Tamoxifen and see how it affects you - I was just done with all the worrying!! Hugs, valerie

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2010 12:41PM vmudrow wrote: Irr493 - I have had 4 fibroadenomas removed, over several years.  Two showed up on mammograms, two I found, the surgeon said they needed to be removed because they are the kind that they don't know what they are until they are taken out - he tried aspirating them, but no fluid.  They were hard and round like a pea.  They all came back benign.  He did lumpectomies though not core biopsy - not sure why.  Anyway try not to worry, some people just have very lumpy breasts and develop those fibroadenomas.  Good luck to you. Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: experience with atypical firbrandenomas? lrr4993 lrr4993

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2011 09:06AM vmudrow wrote: Elibet - when I was diagnoised with ALH (also microcalcifiations) I was sent to an oncologist - who also wanted me to take the Tamoxifen.  He said ALH was precancerous - I also have a very strong family history and had several benign lumps have been removed. I was told that most ladies do not have side effects with Tamoxifen - but I knew a few personally that are on it and can't stand the side effects.  I chose not to take it - and had a PBMX - it might sound drastic, but I was tired of the worry and didn't want to take Tamoxifen.  Good luck - get a couple of different doctor's opinions!!

Posts.Title: ALH farmerlucy Diane5

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 09:49AM vmudrow wrote: Hi, Just wanted to add my 2 cents.  I was diagnoised with ALH at age 49, same as ADH except its in the lobes instead of the ducts.  Because of strong family history (mom, aunt, cousin, grandmother) my mother was tested for gene - negative. Genetic counseling figured my risk was 40% to get breast cancer at some point.   I have been having mammograms since age 30 -at my mom's surgeons instructions.  The last ten years I would have a lump, calcs or something that needed to be biopsied.  I was getting so tired of the worry.  So after being told I had ALH was sent to an oncologist - he strongly recommended Tamoxifen.  After discussing with surgeon (who was very understanding) - I asked her what she would do as I was strongly leaning toward masectomies - she said she was a worrier and would have masectomies.  So that is what I chose.  Is it perfect - no, I am happy I did it - absolutely.  Is still do self exams and see the surgeon once a year because there is a 5% chance something could show up - but it would be very close to the surface.  If anyone is considering this and has any questions, please let me know.  Oh and since it wasn't cancer I was able to have nipple/skin sparing surgery.  Hugs to you all - it's hard worrying all the time, Valerie
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 12:42PM vmudrow wrote: julz4 - when I was diagnoised with ALH - it wasn't a question about taking Tamoxifen - it was highly recommended.  I know you guys have probably seen me state this before - but I was tired of the tests, the worry and didn't want to take Tamoxifen - so had PBMX - and insurance covered it all!!
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2012 09:00AM vmudrow wrote: Carol - so glad to hear it wasn't too bad!!  Fingers and toes crossed for B9!!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2011 02:22PM vmudrow wrote: vamom - hear what your new surgeon has to say - as his/her opinion and then ask if what you want is an option.  Just talk to them and tell them of your concerns.  Let us know - glad you found a new surgeon!!  Hope your results are negative!!

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 10:52PM vmudrow wrote: vamom - sorry to hear the news :(  I knew if my result came back positive I would have PBMX.  Being negative made the decision more difficult, but my risk was figured at 40% - still too high for me - so I did have PBMX.  You will be ok, the surgery was not that bad for me.  Ask PS if you are able to have nipple sparing..  Let me know if you have any questions. Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: awaiting surgery vamom vmudrow

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 02:24PM vmudrow wrote: Hi purelove5 - Sorry you are going through all of this at such a young age.  I am 50 and decided to have masectomies (no cancer, but precancerous cells, and strong family history, negative for BRAC).  The surgery was not bad for me, hospital for one night, pain pills for three days and then tylenol.  I play tennis, bike, hike, gym, etc. and I am able to do everything except (from my plastic surgeon - push ups, bench presses or flys).  It does feel a little weird, but I am getting more and more used to it.  It has been almost a year since my original surgery, and 6 months since my exchange to silicone implants.  Hang in there and keep us posted.  Let me know if you have any questions.  Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: Young, active & Brac1 + purelove5 purelove5

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 04:40PM vmudrow wrote: purelove5 - No I had the tissue expanders with silicone implants latter.  My surgeon said I didn't have enough fat to do a tummy tuck (good thing?) plus she said that does weaken the muscles if cut the stomach muscles or the back muscles.  The plastic surgeon just doesn't want me to do any exercises that are specifically targeted for the pec muscles (he says he sees implants moving toward armpits if the pec muscle it built up)  - anything else is fine.  I went water skiing with the expanders in and bike rides.  It's just hard after both surgery to not be able to do much (I could ride the spin bike) for 4-6 weeks.
Posts.Title: Young, active & Brac1 + purelove5 purelove5

Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 01:35PM vmudrow wrote: purelove5 - are you going to have the cyst removed or masectomy?
Posts.Title: Young, active & Brac1 + purelove5 purelove5

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 01:51AM vmudrow wrote: THANK YOU soooo much for this article.  When my mom was diagnoised 22 years ago with BC (i was 28) I went to her surgeon and said I would like PBMX.  He rightly said that I was over reacting.  So over the years I had several biopsies, etc. the last came back ALH (precancerous) - my new surgeon said that PBMX was an option. My mother was tested -  BRCA negative, but I also had a aunt and cousin that died from BC, genetic counselor said there was probably a unknown mutation.  The surgeon in the article said, "it wasn't just cancer she feared, waiting for test results is torture."  SO TRUE.  I felt relieved after my surgery, even though many were against it (including my mother, which I can't understand), but now that it is a year behind me - I have had many people, including doctor friends say I made a good choice.  As the surgeon in the article stated, "I don't feel brave - I feel lucky."  I too feel lucky!!  The choice may not be right for everyone, but it was for me. Hugs to everyone, Valerie
Posts.Title: High risk breast surgeon undergoes PBM... Soccermom4force alexandria58

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 01:04AM vmudrow wrote: farmerlucydaisy - Soooo sorry to hear this news.  That was my fear going into PBMX.  Hoping your treatment goes well.  Praying for you!!! ndroby - I too think you are making the right decision - as in farmerlucy, who knows what could be lurking in there - hopefully nothing.  I was just soooo tired of the worry and tests etc.  I have been very happy with the outcome of imy PBMX, with implants.
Posts.Title: ALH farmerlucy Diane5

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 06:22PM vmudrow wrote: Kate33 - It was great of  you to start this thread.  I know my surgeon suggested the NSM for my situation, but she said that alot of breast surgeons aren't willing to do it.  She has been interested in it and started doing it about 4 years ago - so I was just lucky I had her, I didn't know it was an option.  I hope people find this site and the information they need.
Posts.Title: Please Read If You Are Considering a Preventative MX Kate33 daniellephillips

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 12:48AM vmudrow wrote: I had propholactic masectomies on May 6th - one drain on each side, couldn't shower until they were removed one week later.  It didn't hurt, I was off pain pills so I drove myself to the appointment.  8 days after surgery went to a movie - not too bad in my opinion. Good luck and hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: Drains notsure Gabrielledr

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 08:44AM vmudrow wrote: yolo - I am kind of suprised that you haven't been put on Tamoxifen.  As soon as I got a diagnosis of ALH I was sent to an oncologist who wanted me on Tamoxifen - that's when I decided I had had enought and had PBMX.  I never had a termogram or MRI, but my doctor said that they do tend to show more - but also show more stuff that needs to be biopsied, but is benign.
Posts.Title: ALH farmerlucy Diane5

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 04:42AM vmudrow wrote: I think you mean a stereotactic biopsy - I had one for calcifications.  It is a weird biopsy, but isn't painful.  Mine came back negative - then 2 years later they wanted to do another - I opted for an excisional biopsy - came back ALH (precancerous).  So try not to worry until you get the results - keep us posted.  Let me know if you have any questions about the procedure. Hugs, Valerie

Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy...so nervous! lford91 lford91

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2011 10:43PM vmudrow wrote: thatsvanity - very touching about your sister.  I too had a strong family history, BRCA negative.  When I got a diagnosis of atypical lobular hyperplasia I too decided prophylactic mastectomies.  There aren't too many of us that have chosen this that aren't BRCA positive, but there are some.  Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: High risk breast surgeon undergoes PBM... Soccermom4force alexandria58

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 06:41PM vmudrow wrote: Tatiana - LCIS is a step above ALH (I think) and I'm not sure but they still might want you to take Tamoxifen even if you have masectomies.  There are other ladies on here that have had masectomies that had LCIS.  I am able to work out, play tennis, bike ride do anything really exept my plastic surgeon does not want me to ever to push ups, flys or bench press.  I kept all my skin/nipple, had tissue expanders, then exchanged them out for saline implants.  I do know some doctors don't believe in nipple sparing (there is more breast tissue left behind), and some just don't do it - it is fairly new.  Good luck - keep us posted!!
Posts.Title: Has anyone had a nipple-sparing skin sparing mastectomy? ScaredInSnoqualmie momoschki

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 09:41AM vmudrow wrote: I was diagnoised with only ALH - but strong family history and doctor agreed that I could have PBMX if I chose - I did - otherwise it would have been Tamoxifen, MRIs, more biopsies, worry etc.  Not the right decision for everyone - but I have been pleased with the whole process.  Good luck - hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: Borderline DCIS-ADH? momoschki momma_of_3

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 10:10AM vmudrow wrote: I was kind of in your situation. At age 49,  I had numberous biopsies, 5 lumpectomies, the latest coming back as atypical lobular hyperplasia, also dense breasts, very lumpy.  My mom had breast cancer at age 60, cousin and aunt also with bc.  The oncologist wanted me to take Tamoxifen, surgeon agreed with close minitoring (MRI yearly), she said be prepared for more biopsies. Had genetic counseling (mom negative for BRCA), my risk was figured at 40% chance of getting bc over my lifetime.  After careful consideration I had nipple/skin sparing masectomies May 2010.  I was tired of the worry every time I had to have a mammo, biopsy etc.  I have been very happy with the results. Not sure how you feel about that, but you could discuss it with your surgeon, mine agreed with me.  Good luck and hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen as preventive? mammafox mvspaulding

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 06:26PM vmudrow wrote: YAY!!
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen as preventive? mammafox mvspaulding

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 09:57PM vmudrow wrote: Anne, My biopsy showed just a tiny amount of ALH.  Maybe because of my high risk they wanted me on Tamoxifen?  It kind of wasn't a choice either - that's why I chose surgery.  For me the surgery was not half as bad as I expected.  I stayed one night in the hospital, pain pills for 3 days, drains out after a week and felt really good.  It's been 2 1/2 weeks and I feel really great - I am totally happy with my decision!! Valerie
Posts.Title: atypical lobular hyperplasia-tamoxifen Myshell vmudrow

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 09:35AM vmudrow wrote: Anne1962 - I think it depends on your risk.  When I was diagnoised with ALH, because there was a strong history of breast cancer in my family I went to genetic counseling and they figured my risk of getting breast cancer (figuring in the ALH) was 40%.  I chose PBM - a little drastic maybe, but I was tired of all the biopsies and scares.  Plus the oncologist wanted me to take Tamoxifen for 5 years, said the ALH is considered pre-cancerous and the Tamoxifen would stop cells from changing to cancer.  I didn't want the side effects of Tamoxifen - so PBM was the best choice for me.  Talk to your doctors - all of them - my surgeon was totally in favor of the masectomies - if I was ready for it.  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: atypical lobular hyperplasia-tamoxifen Myshell vmudrow

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 01:50AM vmudrow wrote: Ilovedisneyland - try not to worry. I have had several lumps removed that sound like yours. They just aren't sure so they want to remove them to be on the safe side. Hope yours are b9. Keep us posted. Hugs, Valerie

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 01:51AM vmudrow wrote: Oh and I Love Disneyland too!!
Posts.Title: Very worried ILoveDisneyland GmaFoley

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 11:04AM vmudrow wrote: cherylmi - Hi, last year I was diagnoised with ALH with a stereotactic biopsy, they also took out a golf ball sized piece of tissue, to analyze.  I was barely an A cup before - so didn't have much to lose.  I was sent to a oncologist who wanted me to start Tamoxifen right away.  I have as strong family history of breast cancer - mom, aunt, cousin (died at 53) - I am 50. So I went for genetic counseling - my mom was tested for BRCA (negative), but they took all my history (previous biopsies etc) and figured my risk to 40% chance of getting breast cancer at some point.  Well, after talking to surgeon (said I would have to have MRIs every year, which show more, which mean more biopsies) and the side effects of Tamoxifen we decided to have nipple/skin sparing masectomies.  I was so done with the tests, worrying everytime.  Happy to say the surgery went well - I didn't have much in the way of breast to loose - I know have silicone implants - and no Tamoxifen, no biopsies, etc.  So happy it is all over.  Wish the best of luck to all you ladies!! Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: lumpectomy tomorrow for atypical cells momcorba vmudrow

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 11:05AM vmudrow wrote: Oh forgot to say that there aren't too many that have masectomies that have ALH only - but it was the right decision for me...
Posts.Title: lumpectomy tomorrow for atypical cells momcorba vmudrow

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 11:55AM vmudrow wrote: Anne1962, No I don't have to take Tamoxifen - the surgery reduced my risk from 40% to less than 5%.  I had nipple, skin sparing masectomies and had tissue expanders put in.  So I go in once a week and have a "fill" until I get to the size I want and then they do an exchange and put in implants.  I don't understand how come some are referred to an oncologist for ALH and some are not.  My surgeon immediately sent me and he said that taking the Tamoxifen was the recommended treatment, it's not like he said I could chose whether to take it or not, he wanted me on it.  Of course I could have declined.  He wanted me on it for 5 years.  It does reduce breast cancer risk, but I didn't want to deal with the side effects.  Good luck.  Maybe ask your surgeon. Valerie
Posts.Title: atypical lobular hyperplasia-tamoxifen Myshell vmudrow

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2011 11:15AM vmudrow wrote: Toni - good luck on Sunday - hopefully you will do great!!  Try not to worry and I think by Christmas you will be feeling pretty good.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 03:30PM vmudrow wrote: vamom - I happen to live in Utah - which is where Myriad is located - the only place that does the testing for BRAC - just interesting that Utah would be the place that does this test :)  and YAY for Curtis!!  If I were you I would wait on any surgery until you get your BRAC results - if it is positve (hope it isn't) then you can decide if you want to have PBMX.  My mom was tested (negative), if she was positive I knew for sure I would have PBMX, being negative I had to take some time to decide.  I did decide on PBMX - I had ALH so insurance covered it.  So glad to be free from all the tests and worry!!!  Let me know if you have any questions - and let us know of your results!! hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: awaiting surgery vamom vmudrow

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 08:33PM vmudrow wrote: rehm046 - my mother, an aunt and cousin, and possibly my grandmother all had breast cancer - but my mom (we had her tested because insurance paid for it) tested negative - so I think I would be negative as well as my 21 year old daughter.  It can also come from your father's side - as well.  The genetic counselor did say that they think it is an unknown mutation with so much in the family.  An interesting note - I think the only place they do the testing is here in Utah at Myriad.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2011 08:25AM vmudrow wrote: traycal - when I met with the oncologist he told me most ladies don't have many side effects from Tamoxifen.  I contacted three ladies that I knew were on it (friends of friends) - all of them hated it and wished they could go off, but didn't dare because they did have breast cancer, one did stop it anyway.  So that helped in my decision, plus I was tired of the constant worry - it was the right decision for me (PBMX), not for everyone though.  Let me know if you have any questions!!  If you would like to call me I could send you my number too.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2010 10:53AM vmudrow wrote: I was diagnoised with ALH in January and surgeon immediately sent me to oncologist.  I had genetic counseling (several relative with bc-negative for BRCA, my risk is 40-50%).  Oncologist wanted to start me on tamoxifen. Returned to surgeon for follow up and after she explained that I would have to have an MRI every year and probably more biopsies (I have had several) I began to rething the tamoxifen.  I personally know a few ladies on it for bc and they hate the side effects.  I have decided to have skin sparing masectomies  - TOMORROW is the day.  The surgeon is totally supportive - I just don't want to sit and wait until I have cancer.  Insurance has approved surgery and plastic surgery - so wish me luck!!

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 10:29AM - edited Jan 26, 2011 10:31AM by vmudrow lintek - I only had a very small amount of ALH on biopsy - my surgeon still thought it important I go see the oncologist and he wanted me on Tamoxifen, even for the small amount, said it is considered precancerous.  I went to the Huntsman Cancer center and had my risk evaluated, they take family history etc. and my risk of getting breast cancer was 40% during my lifetime, so that's kind of why I chose PBM.  Plus I didn't want to take Tamoxifen and have MRIs and biopsies all the time.  I just stayed one night in the hospital - the surgery really wasn't very painful for me - drains yes, but they are just annoying.  Good luck and keep us posted.  Valerie

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2012 10:19PM vmudrow wrote: ED2012 - sorry it is LCIS :(  I was sent to oncologist for ALH - so I'm sure you should go.  One question I would ask is if you had a double masectomy would you have to take Tamoxifen?  I really didn't want to take it and decided for PBMX, so no Tamoxifen or mammograms etc - and  like I said I had ALH not LCIS - just another option, although sounds like your doctor would discourage that course.  Good luck with all your decisions.
Posts.Title: ADH/ALH Are you doing anything different after diagnosis? JayeGA ED2012

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 01:27PM vmudrow wrote: My surgeon was the one who referred me to the oncologist after my biopsy for ALH.  Good luck - keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Do I need an oncologist? DeeLJ DeeLJ

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 04:25PM vmudrow wrote: Do take it seriously.  I was diagnoised with ALH (atypical lobular hyperlasia) and was sent to an oncologist - he wanted me to take Tamoxifen.  I have a strong family history and had multiple biopsies and didn't want to take Tamoxifen or have MRIs every year - which do show more, but need to be biopsied to make sure.  I chose to have PBM - couldn't be more pleased as I felt I was just sitting around waiting to get cancer.  I chose to be proactive - good luck and keep us posted.  Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: High Risk, 3rd biopsy since 2009 lintek vmudrow

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 09:34AM vmudrow wrote: I have had 5 removed, my surgeon likes to remove them because he says you can't know for sure that they are benign unless you remove them.  Good luck, it's a pain I know.
Posts.Title: Another lump!? First was fibroadenoma...what is this? MomOf3inAL MomOf3inAL

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 04:36PM vmudrow wrote: I was fine after the stereotactic - weird test, but not painful - I was just a little sore.  I went shopping after to make myself feel better.  It's nice they are getting you in - its awful sitting around waiting.  Mine came back B9 - that was 3 years ago, then the calcifications were clustering more - had excisional biopsy last year - came back ALH - precancerous.  Sending you hugs and best wishes - keep posting on your results and if you have any more questions - Valerie
Posts.Title: biopsy in the morning . . . maybe stereotactic TrustingHope PegPinGa

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 10:03PM vmudrow wrote: Janyce - GREAT NEWS!  My mother at age 60 had a walnut sized tumor removed, 22 of 24 lymph nodes were positive, dr told my dad that it wasn't a good diagnosis.  Well, it has been 21 years and she has had no recurrence and is doing great!!
Posts.Title: Remind me of the hopeful stories elmcity69 thefuzzylemon

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2012 06:39PM vmudrow wrote: Try not to be nervous, it really isn't bad. Hardest part was lying still, got a stiff neck:). Good luck!!
Posts.Title: Stereotactic Biopsy thoeting sjoyg3

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 02:28PM vmudrow wrote: I think you will get through this.  The surgery wasn't very painful for me at all.  One night in the hospital, 3 days on pain pills, then tylenol, drove myself to doctor a week after to get drains out.  I actually chose this though, I didn't have cancer but ALH (pre-cancer), decided to have double masectomies as a preventitive measure.  I took pictures before, during expansion and after.  Decided to go a little bigger since I had always been small, barely an A, now a C.  So go ahead and go smaller if you want!!  Good luck and here's wishing you the best!!
Posts.Title: guess I am having a mastectomy! edancer hymil

Posts.Content: May 19, 2011 11:23AM vmudrow wrote: Pattimay - sorry about all your problems.  When I was diagnoised with ALH a year ago - I didn't want to take Tamoxifen so after careful consideration (I also didn't want the worry, the constant testing and biopsies) I chose to have PBMX.  I have been happy with my decision.  Keep us posted on how you are doing. Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: ADH questions please pattimay lightning

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 09:35AM vmudrow wrote: I decided to have PBMX after my diagnosis of ALH, they definitely wanted me to take Tamoxifen, but I was tired of the worry, had strong family history and also didn't want to take Tamoxifen.  I have been very happy with my nipple/skin sparing surgery (possible because it wasn't cancer).  There are a few of us who have chosen this route.  Keep up the exercise it's great and will make you feel better.  Hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: ADH/ALH Are you doing anything different after diagnosis? JayeGA ED2012

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 11:19AM vmudrow wrote: So Susskins - have you set a date for your surgery?  If it isn't cancer but only ADH the surgeon might be able to do a nipple/skin sparing surgery and at the same time the plastic surgeon puts in tissue expanders which are filled with saline over a few months and then replaced with silicone implants.  That's where I am in the process and have been pleased/relieved to have the ALH out!!  Good luck!!

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 04:10PM vmudrow wrote: So sorry for the news - but hang in there you will be ok!
Posts.Title: microcalcifications and now... panic! momoschki vmudrow

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 10:18PM vmudrow wrote: My answers are the exactly the same as LISAMG! Make sure you ask if they will do nipple sparing!
Posts.Title: Q's about prophylactic breast surgery beepbeep klynnz

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 12:19PM vmudrow wrote: This is all very interesting - 2 years ago I had microcalcifications, had stereotactic biopsy - B( , then last January mammo showed calcifications were clustering, choice was another stereotactic, but after talking to my surgeon we decided on excisional biopsy (able to get more of a sampling) came back ALH - which my doctors said isn't cancer but precancerous and the oncologist wanted me on Tamoxifen - I chose PBM because of strong family history. So momoschicki you could talk to your surgeon about an excisional biopsy - that way they can tell for sure what is going on - plus I think it isn't as weird/painful as a stereotactic.  Good luck and big hugs, Valerie
Posts.Title: microcalcifications and now... panic! momoschki vmudrow

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 03:49PM vmudrow wrote: ashland6336 - didn't you just love the stereotactic bx?  Must have been designed by a man.  I think they like to take out an area of ADH, just to make sure that there isn't something else there.  Here's hoping the best for you!!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperlasia and double mastectomy susskins CandDsMom

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2010 12:58PM vmudrow wrote: Susskins,  I know exactly how you feel!!  After having 4 benign lumps removed (over several years) and then being diagnoised in January with ALH (like you but in the lobes, not ducts) I wanted to go for the masectomies.  My surgeon agreed, the oncologist suggested Tamoxifen for 5 years - I didn't want the side effects.  I had a double masectomy on May 6, 2010 - and I feel it was the best decision for me.  I didn't want to wait and worry until I got cancer!!  The surgery was not that bad at all - I have had worse.  I was able to have nipple/skin sparing surgery and tissue expanders placed.  They are now filled and I am waiting until September to have then exchanged for implants.  The surgeon, nurses, plastic surgeon, everyone has been very supportive.  If you want to talk I'll PM you my phone number - best of luck!! Hugs,  Valerie
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperlasia and double mastectomy susskins CandDsMom
